strings.introTemplate: Complete these quizzes to build confidence and stay safe during {{topic}}.

sets.title: Before Waters Rise
sets.description: Prepare for flash floods with household steps and planning.

questions.prompt: Which action best reduces flood damage at home?
options: Store items on lower shelves for quick access
Move important documents and electronics to higher shelves
Open balcony doors to let water pass through
Turn on all lights to monitor water level
questions.hint: Keep valuables and documents elevated; water damages paper and electronics.

questions.prompt: Why should you avoid storing items on floor near drains or balconies during the monsoon?
options: They can block drainage and cause indoor flooding
questions.hint: Blocked scupper holes and drains cause water to pond and flow indoors.

questions.prompt: If authorities issue a flood watch, what should you do first?
options: Check local advisories and prepare go-bag
Open windows to cool the house
questions.hint: Monitor official channels and prepare essentials in case you need to leave quickly.

questions.prompt: Which footwear is safest if you must walk through shallow water?
options: High heels to keep feet dry
questions.hint: Closed-toe shoes protect from debris, contamination and slips.

questions.prompt: Where should you place your go-bag at home?
options: At the highest shelf in the bedroom
By the door or an easy-to-grab location
questions.hint: Keep essentials easy to grab in case of quick evacuation.

sets.title: Driving in Floods
sets.description: Know the do’s and don’ts when roads are flooded.

questions.prompt: You encounter a flooded road with unknown depth. What should you do?
options: Turn around and use another route
questions.hint: Never enter floodwaters—vehicles can float in as little as 30 cm of water.

questions.prompt: If water rises rapidly around your parked car, the safest action is to:
options: Stay and wait for help inside the car
Move the car to higher ground if safe, or leave the area on foot
Open doors to let water in
Stand on the roof of the car
questions.hint: Avoid being trapped; head to higher ground if you can do so safely.

questions.prompt: Why is it dangerous to drive around road-closure barriers?
options: They indicate hazards like washed-out roads or deep water
questions.hint: Barriers mark serious hazards. Respect closures.

questions.prompt: After passing through shallow water, you should:
options: Brake hard repeatedly to test ABS
Check brakes gently to dry them
Accelerate to blow water out of the exhaust
questions.hint: Gently applying brakes helps dry them and confirm they work.

questions.prompt: Which is TRUE about electrical hazards in floodwater?
options: Floodwater can hide live wires; avoid contact
questions.hint: Floodwater may be energized; avoid contact and report hazards.

sets.title: After the Flood
sets.description: Steps to stay safe during cleanup and recovery.

questions.prompt: Before re-entering a flooded home you should first:
options: Turn on the main power to check lights
Check for structural damage and smell of gas
Open all sockets to air them
questions.hint: Ensure the structure is safe and utilities are secure before entering.

questions.prompt: When cleaning, which PPE is recommended?
options: Gloves, boots, and mask as needed
questions.hint: Protect against contamination, sharp objects, and mold.

questions.prompt: Food safety after a flood means:
options: Rinse canned food with tap water only
Keep all food that stayed cold
Discard perishable food that was above 5°C for >2 hours or touched floodwater
questions.hint: Contaminated or temperature-abused food is unsafe—discard it.

questions.prompt: Electrical appliances that were submerged should:
options: Be inspected by a qualified technician
questions.hint: Water damages insulation; have appliances inspected before use.

questions.prompt: Which statement about mold is TRUE?
options: Mold starts only after a week
Dry and clean within 24–48 hours to prevent mold growth
Bleach always makes items safe to keep
questions.hint: Quick drying and cleaning prevents mold; some porous items may need discarding.

sets.title: Haze Basics Knowledge
sets.description: Understand PM2.5 and exposure reduction.

questions.hint: PM2.5 are fine particles that can penetrate deep into lungs.

questions.prompt: Best way to reduce exposure outdoors during high PM2.5?
questions.hint: Limit outdoor activity and duration.

questions.prompt: At home, which helps improve indoor air during haze?
options: Use air purifier with HEPA filter
questions.hint: HEPA filters remove fine particles effectively.

questions.prompt: Which mask type provides better filtration of PM2.5 when fitted well?
questions.hint: A well‑fitted respirator (e.g., N95) filters fine particles.

questions.prompt: Who should take extra precautions during haze?
options: Children, elderly, pregnant people, and those with heart/lung disease
questions.hint: Sensitive groups are more affected and need additional protection.

sets.title: Protecting Health
sets.description: Manage symptoms and support sensitive groups.

questions.prompt: If you develop eye or throat irritation from haze, first step is:
options: Reduce exposure and rest in cleaner air
questions.hint: Limit exposure and rest; seek medical advice if symptoms persist.

questions.prompt: For people with asthma during haze, it’s important to:
options: Carry reliever medication and follow action plan
questions.hint: Follow your asthma plan and keep reliever inhaler accessible.

questions.prompt: Hydration during haze is helpful because:
options: It removes all particles from lungs
It supports general health and comfort
questions.hint: Staying hydrated supports comfort though it doesn't filter air.
Combustion and frying generate particles; avoid during haze.

options: Move activities indoors with clean air
questions.hint: Shift activities indoors with cleaner air and adjust intensity.

sets.title: Home & Work Practices
sets.description: Maintain cleaner indoor environments.

questions.prompt: Sealing gaps around doors/windows helps because:
questions.hint: Reducing infiltration improves indoor air quality.

questions.prompt: When using AC during haze, you should set:

questions.prompt: A simple way to make a temporary clean-air room is to:
options: Run a HEPA purifier in a small closed room
Use fans to blow outdoor air inside
questions.hint: Concentrate filtration in a smaller closed space.
Follow the device schedule to maintain performance.

options: Do not touch them—they hold charge

questions.hint: It’s safe to touch; start CPR and call for help.

options: Inside a car with windows closed
questions.hint: Cars act as a Faraday cage; avoid touching metal surfaces.

sets.title: Heatstroke Prevention
sets.description: Learn how to prevent heat-related illnesses before they happen.

questions.prompt: What is the best way to prevent heatstroke during hot weather?
options: Drink plenty of water and stay hydrated
questions.hint: Hydration is key — drink enough water even if you're not thirsty.

questions.prompt: Which clothing is recommended to reduce heat stress?
questions.hint: Lightweight, breathable fabrics help regulate body temperature.

questions.prompt: The best time to schedule outdoor activities during hot weather is:
questions.hint: Avoid peak heat hours and stay cool during extreme temperatures.

questions.prompt: What type of drinks should you avoid in hot weather?
questions.hint: Alcohol and high-sugar beverages can increase dehydration.

questions.prompt: Which of these is a reliable early symptom of heat exhaustion?
options: Sudden chills in a cold room
Shortness of breath only at night
questions.hint: Clammy skin, dizziness, and fatigue indicate early heat stress.

sets.title: During Extreme Heat
sets.description: Stay safe when temperatures rise sharply.

questions.prompt: If you feel dizzy or weak while outdoors in extreme heat, you should:
options: Move to a shaded or air-conditioned place and rest
questions.hint: Rest in a cooler area to prevent heatstroke.

questions.prompt: Which is the safest location during extreme heat?
options: Inside a parked car with windows up
questions.hint: Air-conditioned or shaded places help regulate your body temperature.

questions.prompt: What should you do if someone faints from heat?
options: Call emergency services and move them to a cool place
Splash very hot water on them
Force them to walk it off
questions.hint: Call for help and cool the body while waiting for assistance.

questions.prompt: Children and elderly are at higher risk because:
options: They are weaker and less able to regulate body temperature
questions.hint: Both groups need extra protection during heatwaves.

questions.prompt: What is the immediate danger of staying in a parked car during heatwaves?
questions.hint: Temperatures inside parked cars can rise dangerously fast.

sets.title: After Heatstroke / Recovery

options: Ignore the episode if you feel better

questions.prompt: Which cooling method is NOT recommended?
options: Wet towels on neck and armpits

Immersing the person in ice-cold water abruptly
Using a fan to increase airflow
questions.hint: Abrupt ice immersion can cause shock in heatstroke victims.

questions.prompt: After recovery, what’s important to prevent future episodes?
options: Stay hydrated, plan breaks, and monitor heat advisories
questions.hint: Hydration and preparation are the best prevention strategies.

questions.prompt: One sign of severe heatstroke is:
questions.hint: Confusion and fainting indicate medical emergency.

questions.prompt: Which group should be monitored closely after heatstroke?
questions.hint: These groups face higher complications; extra monitoring is vital.
